title: Outstanding system
text: I’ve had the nest thermostat for almost a year now, and I can say it’s money well spent. First, it was very easy to install. The instructions are easy to follow; I did not have to do any rework. I did not have to hire a professional. Programming the controls was also easy with step by step instructions. I like the fact that it self programs economic settings based on when you’re home. I’m single and working so it’s nice to know it is saving me money by reducing back the heating and cooling temps when I’m not home. And it does it automatically through a sensor that detects motion. This could, however, be a problem if you have a big dog. You can also control the settings using your smart phone, which is what I do pretty much all the time. I can even control it from work and by using Google voice. This system requires a dependable WiFi. If the WiFi goes off line, however, as it has done with me a few times, the system will still function but you won’t be able to control it from you smart phone. Once the WiFi is back on line, the thermostat will automatically resume previous settings. And best of all, it has saved me hundreds of dollars in utility savings. And it looks sharp on the wall. Well worth the money, and so easy for DIY’ers. Definitely worth a five-state rating!!

title: Replacement Thermostats
text:
I’ve had Honeywell internet-compatible thermostats in my house for nearly six years, and they just stopped communicating with the internet after multiple calls with service.  Luckily I got them at Costco!  Costco returned them with no issues, and they also happened to have Nest thermostats available too.  So I got a full refund for the old thermostats, and bought two new Nest Version 3 thermostats (as my house is divided into two areas).  Replacing the first thermostat took a little longer than the second, as it was just getting to know how the unit works and confirming the wire schematic.  The first unit connected to my router with no problems, but the second one kept failing at first.  I ended up temporarily moving the second unit to the first unit’s location and got it to connect.  After I moved it back to its correct location, it was still connecting ok.  

The only reason I gave it 4 out of 5 stars was that the actual application kept disconnecting after both thermostats were connected, and several times during installation.  It’s almost like it reset, and you’d have to start the install from the beginning again with the Nest app.

title: Frustrating
text: The products themselves are excellent quality.  But this app is a huge disappointment. It has such a high latency rate - you open the app and it takes 45 seconds to load up to the main menu. (It’s not my wifi or cellular connection) So let’s consider this: your doorbell rings. You open the app, wait 45 seconds, then navigate to the doorbell where you can access the microphone and begin talking. At that point, the interaction time has been about 55 seconds. Most people, after ringing a doorbell, won’t stay at the door that long, thus by the time I can finally get to the mic the person is gone and the feature is no longer useful. Additionally, it’s a pain to guard nest guard with the app. I’ll tap the shield and it will load for 30 seconds and then say it can’t connect. I do it again. Can’t connect. After 5 or 6 times it will FINALLY arm the system. A last complaint I have is that nest is no longer integrated with HomeKit. It was previously before the company was purchased by Google. I get that Google instead wants you to use the Google home system however, as an avid Apple user, it’s frustrating to have to use 2 systems. We chose Nest because the physical products are far beyond the competition but there are some serious rooms for improvement for this application. Reduce network calls on app launch, considering auditing latency for the app and see where the problem lies, and please integrate with HomeKit.

title: Great, intuitive, useful app for a great product (Nest thermostat).
text:
I bought this thermostat at the same time I replaced my HVAC system a couple weeks ago, but I wish I'd gotten one sooner. I'm sure I've already saved money, because the learning function has already made it WAY easier to maintain a comfortable temperature, and I don't forget that I have the AC or heat on, and overshoot a comfortable temperature.  I was really impressed how quickly it learned my habits, and began preempting my changes, so I find I'm quickly losing the habit of constantly thinking about the temperature, and I haven't found  myself uncomfortable enough to be reminded since about day 2. It's really cool to be able to control it from my phone, but I find the more technical controls useful, and the data it records and aggregates is just as interesting and useful. I know this is supposed to be a review for the app, not the thermostat, but it's really just an aspect of the same product, so I believe it's relevant. It IS a solid, intuitive app, user friendly & well laid out, and it's an app for an undeniably great product.

Pricey, but absolutely worth it.

title: One small thing that makes a big difference to me
text: The app itself works well.  There are periods of time through the year where I would just like to run the fan on my furnace without being in heating or cooling mode.  The nest thermostat can run the fan by itself, but when doing so it must be in heating or cooling mode.  In spring, I like to circulate cool air from the basement through the house.  I also like to leave windows open for fresh air, and circulate that air too.  There are days where it’s 80* during the day and 50* at night.  These are perfect days to leave windows open and periodically run the fan.  However, for this to work with the nest, I have to set the cooling mode on and use a cooling set point above 80* to make sure the air conditioning isn’t coming on wastefully while windows are open.  It’s not the end of the world, but an item that I believe should be simple functionality that would bring me to like the product better.  If it worked as I would like it to, I could check in on the temperature with the app and run the fan during the day, without having to mess around and closely monitor temperatures.

title: Nest Thermostat App
text:

-well built.  
-easy to install
-built in lithium ion battery backup
-Geofencing.
-runs fan after the heat turns off for a couple minutes to get the rest of the heat out of the ductwork instead of heating the walls.

Cons

text:

There is one workaround: create a bogus gmail account and use that only for Nest app. So I did that, because let’s face it, I got a smart thermostat so I didn’t have to get out of bed at 3 am to adjust the thermostat! Worked fine for a day but now my account is offline and the Nest solution is to restart my router and disrupt all the other services and devices on my router so Nest can find my wifi signal again!

title: A Life Saver!!
text:
My 80 year old mother lived by herself and started falling. One day after several people tried contacting her by phone, I went to check on her and found her laying on her bathroom floor. Upon paramedics arrival they estimated she had been on the floor for a couple of hours due to dry blood from where she hit her head due to a fall.
That’s when Nest cameras came into our lives !!!
I needed something I could check on her without drilling into apartment walls that was not allowed. My brother suggested and came and set up 2 camera’s. One in her living room and one in her bedroom.
My mom has Alzheimer’s and Dementia and has lived with 2 alternating caregivers for almost 3years now.
I can keep a close eye on her, I have been able to assist the caregivers in time of need and my moms confusion by talking to my mom through the cameras and I cannot stress how these cameras has tremendously and so outstanding has helped to keep my mother home and safe and has been absolutely a BLESSING TO HAVE!!

title: Operator difficulty
text: I’m a self employed contractor for a well known satellite company. It might rhyme with fish, who knows. I install and teach all Nest products for customers wishing to purchase them. title: Missing basic features and old design
text:
The app works but is not that user friendly and lacks of basic features, probably because of its old design. The support of the sensors is done like a patch (when you are able to add them…in my old apartment I had a ticket open for 3 months before getting it fixed and being able to add them), meaning that is not properly designed and integrated. You can see the temperatures of the different sensors but you can only set one sensor to trigger the AC manually or based on only 4 time slots of the day, regardless of the day of the week, which is a big limitation. Should it be clever enough to calculate the average of the temperature of all the sensors of the house and use it to set the temperature or the average of specific sensors? Yes, it should…but it doesn’t!! What a big disappointment.
Last: there is no “snooze” / pause button if you want to temporarily stop the air from blowing : you have to change the temperature to do that and then change again when you want it to start again.

I think it’s time to rethink completely at the app with the features in mind of the 2021.

title: Slow and finicky
text:
Like all these types of apps, there is a delay activating it and connecting to the sensors or cameras. 
I also found it impossible to get three thermostats to connect. They seem to connect on their own mesh network and so even if you have strong WiFi the devices may not all register and see each other. I had to fake a second house to get the one in my basement to work at all. It’s fine, but it’s not connected to the other two sensors and it seems that’s part of the benefit as they are supposed to work together. 

One final point. If your electric goes out, you have a 1-2 hour back up battery. After that you have no heat. I have not tested this but thats important to know if you are dealing with heavy winter storms. I was surprised that the back up battery was not of longer duration. Seems like an easy solve. 
I would recommend keeping either your old thermostats in case you need them in an emergency or having some way to charge the nest faceplate if you had to. (There is a USB port but haven’t tested that and again you will take an hour or three to charge it for an hour or two of use. Not ideal).

title: Literally a Life Saver
text:
You never know how valuable something is (or if it even works!) until you *have* to. For us, that experience was with our Nest Fire and CO2 detector. When we needed to replace old detectors, I chose to pay a little more for Nest. Would it pay off; would it be worth it? We figured probably not, but we installed them anyway. 

This holiday season, we were 900 miles away - certainly not thinking of home. At church, I went to silence my phone & noticed a Nest alert that there was smoke detected in our home. Surprisingly calm, I called our local fire dispatch & contacted neighbors and family. By the time the fire department arrived, smoke filled our home. The cause: an overheated furnace! 

Our home was likely saved because of that Nest alert. We can deal with minor smoke damage! That decision to buy a Nest product made all the difference in the world. It worked exactly as expected, when needed most, and we are forever grateful.

title: So far, so good
text:
We’ve had the Nest for about 6 months now, and while I don’t know if it’s saving us any money by using, it is so nice to be able to set it to a specific temperature vs. the old thermostat which had the little slide lever on the bottom, and you slide it to the right for a higher temp or to the left for a lower temp, but there was no indication as to what actual temp you were sliding it on to. 

I also love that I can control the Nest from my phone. If I’m in bed and want the temp moved up or down you grab your phone and change it. That said you can also program it to be a certain temp at a certain time of day. This is great in the winter time, when everyone is out of the house at school or work, and want the house warmed a bit by the time everyone gets home. 

While we haven’t yet gotten into the full swing of summer, I highly recommend the Nest. Its easy to use and makes controlling the temps in your home a breeze.

title: “Learning” thermostat
text: As I write this review, it is completely appropriate that I cannot see any of the words I am writing in the  Nest app.  It is really funny, actually.  Maybe it’s be because I’m giving the entire ecosystem 2 stars. Sadly, to say Nest is “learning” would be a misnomer. I can set a schedule and within seconds, go back to it and find that Nest has changed that schedule, sometimes drastically. Sometimes, especially in the summer, despite me being home and despite me walking past either of our Nest thermostats, I’ll notice that the thermostats have crept up to terribly hot levels, I conducive to comfort or even to a person’s health. title: Resolved our problems
text:
We have a large home with 12 smoke alarms. We have had issues for 4 years with the standard smoke detectors going off randomly all at once with humidity and other times where they went off all at once for no apparent reasons. The fire department had to come out 3 times and our electrician came out several times to try and troubleshoot the problem. We narrowed it down to the smoke alarms. 

I knew I needed a very high quality and intelligent smoke alarm that could isolate which smoke alarm had the issue. I also wanted to have access to know if the smoke alarm was functioning properly. Nest Home Protect had all of the technology we needed and we just installed  all 12 yesterday and we love how they operate. It was an expensive option but well worth the peace of mind knowing we do t ha e to listen to the chirps and guess which alarm needs a battery. I would highly recommend this to anyone!

title: It used to be great
text: When I first purchased the indoor cameras, motion detectors, nest aware etc everything worked great. That lasted a few months. Not sure if this is an issue with the app unable to communicate with the hardware or the hardware not communicating with the app. Now I get reminders to set alarm when we are home, constantly. Unfortunately I’m “stuck” with all the nest hardware and therefore the app. I’d recommend going with something else that has better value for your money.

title: Endless Buffering
text: I’ve had 2 nest outdoor cameras at my home for several years and my experience can be summed up in the title of the review. The lag/buffering is atrocious. I’ve tested the WiFi signal strength from each camera’s location and get full signal from both spots. Also worth mentioning I have gigabit internet along with a top of the line modem & the Rolls Royce of routers from Netgear and everything else in the house runs flawlessly. It’s extremely frustrating when you hear a strange noise during the night and open the app to check your cameras only to be greeted by a never ending spinning blue circle. Don’t bother calling customer service, they will inevitably tell you that you have subpar connection or slow internet speeds. title: The worst smart thermostat and app
text:
As far as the app goes, it keeps getting disconnected (sometimes 4 times in 5 seconds) from the nest and sometimes what you set in the app is not actually set in the nest or it does not reflect the nest state if you go to the actual device, you will see. This has been very annoying and frustrating since I paid so much for a darn thermostat just to be able to control it remotely and for a bit of smarts.

Now for the actual Nest thermostat itself. The device looks pretty, but smart would not be amongst the words I would use to describe it. Once it latches on to a setting (“learns it”) it is almost impossible to change the setting. If it wants to set the temp to 70, and you feel like you want to change it, it will change it back. You can’t turn off the smarts completely. You have to reset it completely to get rid of what it has learned, but then it will learn again and you will be in the same place. There are multitude of other very annoying and frustrating flaws with this thing which would take much more to explain. Don’t wast your time or money on this over priced thing. I wish I hadn’t.

title: Temp won’t stay in the ranges I need. In April I think I caught C
text:
Covid. My lumbar region was puffy, I was having severe difficulties I think I caught Covid but there were no test kits available. I had difficulties breathing, ran fever, my heart was racing at times and when my b/p was taken it was usually high.

title: Great products
text: I have 8 Nest Smoke detectors and the door lock. The smoke are great if you have a dog,a voice gives you a warning that it detects smoke and that the alarm will sound and the alarm is loud. That gives you time to cancel the alarm before it sounds. My dogs don’t stress out for a false alarm anymore. The night light option is fantastic. Then the thermostat which was the first Nest product I bought is the best of the lot. It learns our schedule and then it automatically adjusts the temperature accordingly. title: Google made it too buggy
text: I loved my Nest camera when I first bought it. I loved the “home/away” features to turn on/off automatically. title: If only...
text:
ThIS REVIEW IS FOR THE APP

But seeing how you can't separate the device from the app, there is some crossover.

title: Nest Camera Helps Save My Dog
text:
This camera has been a life saver, literally but before we get to here are the important bullet points:

title: Common Wire
text: Nest system is great, overall. In love with keyless entry. I have the Nest learning thermostat - my old thermostat had only 2 wires. The R (power) and the W (heat). What I found is the R wire is NOT Enough to generate enough power to maintain a wifi connection and then my furnace shut down. And it seems like a problem a lot of people have with the Nest. I wish that this was something addressed in the installation of the Nest and I do think it should come with a charger for those who may not have a common wire to increase the power. Thankfully I did purchase new wiring with a third C wire (common) to boost the electrical input for power but it took too much research and during a time while I was researching I wasn’t able to have heat during a very cold month. text:

title: Good thermostat for landlords
text:
First it does what it’s supposed to do. Also tec support is good.

For heat I program it at 70 but they can raise it to 72. After a couple of hours it goes back to 70. Also because I have 1 thermostat for 4 apartments I can monitor the other tenants actual room temperature with the remote sensors. 
     I enjoy peaking on my phone to see if everything is working properly. Once I figured out that the apartment with the thermostat was running a space heater. I realized this by looking at the thermostats temperature and seeing the other apartments where colder. 
    Also I once realized before anyone called me that the boiler had a issue. A pipe had developed a leak and would run a few minutes and turn off. It saved me from a lot of water damage. title: Control Logic Correction Needed
text:
I really like my Nest Thermostat. The ability to control remotely is awesome and the thermostat looks great!

There is one aspect that will significantly improve the performance and that is related to the control logic. When I set the upper and lower temperature control values, I notice that the Nest controller does not actually control to these temperature settings. The Nest controller actually allows the actual temperature to go higher than the maximum temperature (by about one degree F) before it sends the signal to the air conditioner to turn on. It also allows the actual temperature to go lower than the minimum temperature (about one degree F) before sending the signal to the heater to turn on. This situation is quite annoying and I find that I have to manually adjust the temperature settings in order to turn on my HVAC System. I even looked through the settings to see if there is an adjustment I can make to the tolerance in the control logic but could not find such a function. 

I understand that there may need to be a lag in order to ensure the A/C or heater is not cycling on and off too quickly in order to protect my HVAC System, but the situation I am experiencing is not a rapid on or off situation that would damage my unit. 

Therefore, I am humbly asking Nest to please fix this control logic issue and I will change to a 5 star rating.

title: Nest is the Best!
text:
I have owned several DVR/NVR home video surveillance systems throughout the years and I have been pleased with the video quality of those devices, but the one feature I’ve always complained about was the playback/video review.  

Prior to becoming a Nest customer, I was hesitant to purchase their product because of the monthly subscription.  One year, I got a camera as a gift and tried their free trial.  I knew it was going to take more than the video quality to become a customer.  So, I tried it and once I tested the playback feature I was completely sold. I could not believe how easy it was to review 24 hours of data in less than a minute.  The cloud based Nest home surveillance system is the way to go.  Since my first camera, I purchased two other cameras, to include, the Nest Ring Doorbell.

title: Feature randomly disappears
text:
Over the past year, my Nest experience has become progressively worse. The camera used to be rock solid, almost always connected, and picked up pretty much all motion correctly. (Occasionally a person would be detected as generic motion and vice versa)

But a few months back my camera started having random outages unrelated to WiFi, happening a handful of times each week. This seems to have slowed down but is still an occasional thing. There’s no release notes for firmware updates in the app or online, and they happen silently. This means I can’t check to see if a recent update may be causing issues.

The worst issue is that currently very obvious motion events intermittently aren’t even recorded on the timeline at all. A person leaving the front door, the entire car leaving the driveway, people walking up to the front door. I cannot trust the camera anymore, the one thing that sold me on Nest in the first place. Multiple people have reported this same exact issue on the forums for months with no resolution.

title: Familar and unfamiliar faces
text: When nest sends you a pop up image and asks you to tag a face as familiar or unfamiliar and you tag “unfamiliar” that face is lost forever.  They also give no warning that this loss will occur.  why would you mark an unfamiliar face as familiar?  Therefore if that unfamiliar person broke into your home, their image is lost and if the video is not great you have no image of your criminal.  I spent much time this holiday trying to explain this to Nest service chat and they had no clue this was an issue.  After a long chat that went no where i asked to escalate to a supervisor.   I had to explain the problem again and That person told me they would escalate the issue and let me know if there’s a solution but not alert me if there wasn’t.  Thoughtless!  Im glad i learned this difficult lesson about unfamiliar faces and Nests poor customer service when we did not have an actual break inso we can hope to avoid a future issue.

title: Apple Watch Motion Video Previews Broken
text: After months of back and forth with technical support, they still have yet to fix this widespread issue. After a certain update near the middle of September the Motion Video previews on the Apple Watch became a still image instead of a playable video preview. My business relies on this feature heavily. I knew something was sorely wrong when I noticed the triangular play button no longer existed. I’ve been told that my issue has been given to multiple higher tier technicians, but still the issue has not been fixed. They have had me do numerous things, all have had no bearing on it being fixed. I brought this to their attention at the end of September, it’s now November 21 & the feature has still not been fixed. I keep asking for updates, but it still has not been fixed. I’ve now resorted to posted a 1 star review in hopes that my case will be taken seriously & to also warn others of this problem. I hope a fix is paramount, but for now, I continue to, unfortunately, wait. Thank you.

title: The best digital thermostat
text:
I had a Nest and moved to a new home with an Ecobee.  It never worked right and after 5 (not exaggerating) visits by two different AC companies, I realized it was my Ecobee not catching and not turning the air on. I called the company and after the most passive aggressive customer service rep from Ecobee who offered zero answers that could help me, I told them I am going back to the Nest.  

It has been two weeks with my new Nest installed and zero issues with my AC and a way easier interface that actual works unlike the Ecobee and that is way more user friendly.  I have air conditioning again that works which is super important since I live in Florida.  

Don’t waste your time with wanna “bee” companies and stick with the Nest.  Their products actually work and do what they say!!

title: Works but needs a refresh
text:
We use a nest cam indoors and we also have a nest thermostat. Both of these products are awesome and the app works well to control everything related to them. However, the app layout itself can be frustrating. When I am full screen in the camera, it’s easier to force close the app and reopen to get to the Home Screen (to access my thermostat) than to figure out how to just go back within the camera screen.
You also have to go into the camera full screen in order to turn it off, which is annoying considering there is a toggle to turn it on from the Home Screen.
Anyway, it does work well and everything, we love the products we have and being able to use the app to view/control. But the usability when you have more than one type of product connected to it needs some work.

title: Seriously?
text:
For being the original smart home thermostat, you’d think they’d have a pretty polished product by now, but NOPE. I don’t have much issue with the thermostat itself, it’s about as straightforward as any non-smart thermostat, the problem is the unintuitive dumpster fire that is the app. 

To be fair, the main problem is the scheduling section, but since that is literally THE most important function of the app, I don’t feel too bad calling the whole thing a failure. 

The schedule section has no instructions, no tooltips, and is unintuitive. It has buttons that are apparently useless, or if they do do something, then they’re missing stuff. I’m talking about the ‘copy week’ button. What weeks? There is no month view, there is no ‘next week’ or ‘previous week’ button, there is no ‘make this the default’ option. So when I go through and individually set every temperature (a process just begging for some sort of convenience feature), I am rewarded by having it completely garbled the following week when for some reason the app tries to merge my changes with what it thought that next week should be, resulting in 30 minute windows of the temperature I actually wanted. And of course there’s no option to turn off the schedule feature and just leave it at a set manual temperature. 

I bought this house with a Nest already in it, and I will be removing it in favor of a competitor that has some semblance of quality control in their interface design.

title: Not real happy with Google Nest
text:
Before Google got involved with Nest it seems my Nest cameras and thermostat connect with my iPhone very well. The internet signal always tests “Excellent”, but most of the time I use the Nest app to check the thermostat all I get is searching and a notice to try later or that my internet is not strong enough to upload the data. The Thermostat is approximately 15 feet from the internet “tower”. The interior camera is approx. 10 feet away. Exterior camera is approximately 40 feet away. I used to get excellent and fast response. Nothing has changed physically, but the connection is sporadic at best since Google has gotten involved.
I would really like to talk with someone about this. But I can’t find a phone # to call a Nest tech rep. All I can find are “help” screens and they don’t solve the problem . I have a $1,000 invested in these cameras and a thermostat and most of the time they are useless.
Not Happy with Google Nest

title: Connection issues multiple times daily & thermostat glitchy
text: I’ve had the nest thermostat and app for four years. I’ve had the nest doorcam for a few months. Both devices are conveniently integrated on the nest app. While I absolutely LOVE the nest devices themselves, the app has many issues. The two most prominent issues I’ve encountered (aka daily annoyances) are: 1) two seconds after opening the app, it will act as if I have signed out and says “There was a problem connecting to the nest service. Try again in a few minutes” and if touch the back-button and try it again it’ll either work just fine or keep doing that; and 2) app-thermostat glitches when adjusting the temperature (e.g., drag the temp tab to adjust the temperature and it glitches back to what it was previously, or use arrows to adjust temp and it glitches back to what it was previously). I am surprised that google has developed such a glitchy application. I hope that these issues are addressed soon! Till then, the nest app is not rated high by me.

title: Consistently logs out, makes cameras unusable
text:
I constantly get logged out with the issue “There was a problem connecting to the Nest service. Try again in a few minutes.”
When this happens it loses my place. This has been happening for over a year, but it’s been getting worse and worse recently.
An easy way to reproduce a similar issue is to disconnect a camera for a few minutes and then later try and scroll to that time. Instead of seeing a message like “footage not available at time X” it kicks you out and loses your place. In my case, however, my cameras are recording just fine and it still kicks me out with the same error. Google should be able to at least fix the offline camera issue first and then see if that improves this app. Note that I did just switch my Nest account to a Google account thinking it would help with this. It in fact makes it much worse because if it doesn’t auto log back in you now have to log in to Google with 3 or 4 taps instead of the usual 1.

title: The software is barely useful.
text: The basic idea works ok but the usefulness trails off quickly. A few issues if you have motion alerts on (which is a big reason to have this premium product in the first place): 1. no matter how you set the detection zones, they can’t discern if a car passes by in the distance versus a bush blowing in the wind versus a person is walking by closely. 2. same as #1 but at night, any motion of bugs or birds flying in the zone triggers an alert. 3. captured images of people’s faces are small & can’t be expanded to get a better look at them and/or brighten/darken the image for clarity - thus you can’t properly identify many people that should be in your People tab. 4. Unable to edit new & delete saved faces in the People tab. With so many false alerts coming through, you might start to ignore them which means a real alert is ignored. There should be options to switch “ignore x” algorithms off & on as desired so you get alerted only for the items really desired. Then add the options to the People tab.

title: NEST thermostat
text: Since this miami apt is my second home, I wanted to be able to set my temp at 73 while I’m away for 8 mo.     It is not that easy to set up like a regular manual thermostat.  Several features specific to NEST must be turned OFF   One needs to override the ‘learning’ feature, turn off the schedule function, and also turn off the Eco function.    Otherwise the apt won’t be kept at 73.    It would most likely end up warmer and more humid than the set temp since NEST works best when a living thing is moving and is detected in the apt.    The Eco feature keeps the temp higher as this is an energy saving feature.    I don’t want my energy saved.  I want to keep it at a specific temp.     Last season when I came back, my stainless refrigerator door had rusted     And the whole refrigerator had to be replaced $$$$$$.    Was not worth the energy savings

title: Glitchy!!!
text: This app is so glitchy!! My alarm take about 6 tries to set.  Continuously tells me that “it’s taking a while to connect” after about 3 seconds.  Constantly wants me to re-login.  Same thing when it comes to the door locks.  Don’t get me started on setup.  Takes MANY tries to get it to connect.  Doing nothing different, it will eventually connect.  I have had so many issues with this app and how buggy it is.  Away from my home currently and can’t get alarm to set.  Nothing but a constant pain.  The app is useless.  Still have to manually set the alarm.  Manually work the locks - does not work as advertised.  Wanted the entire Nest suite of products but now have major regrets.  Not at all a cheap product and you certainly don’t get what you pay for in my opinion!  Update: after several days of pure frustration with the app, I’ve taken my Nest Guard back to the store and have switched to Ring.  MUCH better user experience and reliable interface.  Bonus, it’s cheaper too! Don’t waste your time on Nest.

title: Nest product is great, the app is a little difficult at install
text:
The app was fine until during install, you need to restart the install every time the phone screen goes to sleep. So that’s annoying. Otherwise, I got the Nest installed within the 30 minutes they estimate it takes to setup a new Nest.

The Nest product adds all kinds of sensing abilities in order to know if you’re home or away and if your humidity is high or low. The Nest app has improved greatly and allows one to add multiple people to nest thermostat so that when anyone is home, it can do the appropriate things.
The Nest app seems to handle many of the configurations that you would possibly need. For example, if you have a large house with multiple Nest thermostats, it does the right thing to support that. It also supports having multiple houses with Nest apps!

title: Nest Yale Lock
text:
Unlike the other Nest products, which I love, the 3 door locks I bought will no longer allow me to add “guests” (IE:contractors, cleaning staff) on the Nest app.  This happened when Nest merged with Google.  The error message I got was “Oops.  Something went wrong. Try again.” One website said I needed to merge my Nest with Google. DON’T DO IT. 
I’ve been through several specialists who aren’t able to figure out what went wrong.  I was asked to remove a guest and the reinstated.  I removed my guest but couldn’t add him again.  I went through several tries with the specialists and after I lost the 3rd guest, I said no more.  
Anyway, I’m hoping this won’t or hasn’t happened to you. 
While I’m keeping the other Nest products (Until Google ruins them as well. =) I’m looking at other remote doorlocks.

title: Good but kinks
text: The app is nice and easy to use. I have issues with programming the thermostat though. I set a schedule, which is a bit more tedious than pushing a button, and then it reverts back for no apparent reason and I have to reset it all over again. It’s fairly annoying when I’m trying to be efficient with more cooling during the nights when it’s not sunny and letting the system take a break as the sun warms up the house to a higher daytime setting. I just wish if you set a schedule it would stay that way. I appreciate some of the learning features, although I felt they used to be more accurate than recently, picking up on common times I’m away from home and giving the system a break. I have overall saved money with it, however, some of the features don’t seem to stay how you want them.

title: Not so smart
text:
This review is for the Nest Thermostat. We've had it for 5 years now.

I quickly learned to turn off the auto learning because all it does is track the time and temperature you're setting. That's good enough in winter but in summer it's different. When it's hot and dry I can easily take 80F in the house during the daytime. When it's hot and humid I need 77F. The thermostat never learns this - it just doesn't take the humidity level into account. That's not "Smart" in my opinion.

There's also no way to manually adjust the cool to dry feature's humidity level. I'd like to have it at 70% max. That's not possible, so I keep adjusting the thermostat manually, setting it to 77F, then back to 78F a little later because it runs too long. 

At other times, it's clearly above my desired temperature and the thermostat just doesn't feel like it's necessary to run the AC.

As countless others have mentioned, the app has connection problems. It's either super slow, shows the thermostat as offline, or does nothing. It's been like that for all the years we've had the thermostat. Absurd.

All of these problems have persisted over the years. I don't think I'd buy one again, and now that Google pushes for the account integration, it's all the more reason to think twice before getting a Nest, and carefully look at the competition.

title: Best Cameras Out There.
text: We originally started out with the Ring Doorbell and was going to use the Ring Cameras when I realized you can’t mount them under the roof soffit because they are strictly made to mount horizontally. I called Ring to see if there was another option and they said no. I told the rep that was crazy he then gave me the email to the guy who founded the company. I sent him an email and he responded the reason they don’t make them for under the soffit is because water intrusion. Of course I had to respond back told  him we can send a spacecraft to Mars release a rover and it can ride all over that planet and send back photos but Ring can’t develop a water resistant camera? Well I’m glad we purchased Nest products our cameras quality is amazing and the service is second to none.

title: The Air That I Breathe
text:
I just installed a learning Nest thermostat at a second home, and after becoming familiar with all its features I now say I should have done this years ago. 
No longer do I have to worry about the temp being at the condo required setting while away for periods of time, I can also run the HVAC fan periodically throughout the day for circulation by simply touching the Nest app on my phone. 
The most appreciated feature is to either turn on the AC or heat before I arrive so there isn't an hours wait time to walk in to a comfortable air space.  
Installation was easy, and the tutorial the unit walked me through was great; anyone with a screwdriver should be able to install this unit. 
I'll be getting one for the HVAC at my primary residence for all the same reasons. 🌞☃️

title: Camera is great, app leaves a lot to be desired
text: I use my Nest indoor camera for security when I’m not home, and since I work nights in a big new city it’s important for it to be functioning when I’m gone. I’ve had issues with the app since I got the camera in July, but after merging with Google it’s gotten so much worse. When I’m not home the camera is constantly offline, even when my phone is at 5 bars, and all other apps are working perfectly. Since the merge, whenever this happens the app also automatically logs me out entirely. This defeats the purpose of having a security camera, since it only seems to work when I’m in the immediate vicinity of my home’s WiFi. I had the camera on the other day and was never notified of someone from my apartment’s maintenance inside my home. The camera was offline, and I had no way of knowing until I opened the app to check. The app doesn’t even alert me when the camera is offline anymore.

title: Review of whole set up
text:
I have an entire set up for nest. I have the door bell, nest IQ outdoor camera, another outdoor camera, 2 indoor cameras, thermostat and security system. These items are not cheap by any means and don’t get me wrong, they are great products but the app is terrible. Every single time I leave the house I cannot get on to see my cameras. It logs me off and makes me sign back in through good which takes a good 5 min each time. If someone rings my door bell, by the time I can load the app and open the doorbell camera, the person is long gone. It picks up people as a “motion” which I know they create motion but then they are in my driveway or by my front door, it would be nice to know there is a person at my house. 
The cameras as so laggy and delayed with the app feed it’s about 15-30 seconds behind. It would be great if there can be major adjustments in the actual app to fix this issues since we all spend so much money on the product

title: Auto Schedule
text: I set my auto schedule to run all week at 72 during the day and 70 at night and my thermostat keeps running the A/C at 69 F even when I’m not home and I’ve set my auto schedule thermostat manually and on this app multiple times to run at 72 during the day and 70 overnight and my A/C just keeps running continuously during the day when I’m not even home. I keep setting it at 70-72 and it just changes the A/C to run at 69. Then I wake up covered in sweat overnight because it’s not running at all. What’s the point of setting auto schedule or even manually adjusting the thermostat when it just runs whenever it wants to at the temp it’s not supposed to be running at? My utility bill is gonna be SO high because the system is overriding any manual or automatic setting. Anyway to fix this? I have a friend who’s gonna come look at the unit but I’m scared for what my bill is going to look like.

title: Unsatisfied
text: My Nest thermostat (Gen 3) was installed less than 2 months when there were messages on the screen about the failed connection to the wi-fi. I called Nest and after walking through the trouble shooting steps, the Nest Tech confirmed the network chip had failed and the thermostat had to be replaced. The Tech got his supervisor’s approval to send the replacement overnight. After 3 or 4 days I received an email indicating the thermostat was shipped. In their email they had mentioned that I will get another email with return label for the defective thermostat. I finally received the replacement yesterday. However there is no email in sight with the return label! The technician did a good job pinpointing the problem. The company did a lousy job fulfilling what they promised! I gave 2 stars one to recognize the designers and developers efforts for this product and the other for the technician’s effort and zero star  for quality control and customer satisfaction effort!!!

title: Need update for constant false alerts
text: I love the nest products. I think they are very well made. But when the app you have to use them with is crap it kind of defeats the purpose. I have nest protect with multiple cameras. Keep getting false alerts even when I turn off settings to be notified (not safe). It constantly thinks I’m away even though I’m home. The software in the cameras can’t detect the difference between a car and a person. Also can’t tell the difference between daylight changes and a person. I even have notification zones set up and still notifies me of things outside of notification zone. I never use to have any of these issues and I feel like this happened all of a sudden in the last 6 months. Once my system gets old and no longer works, I will probably switch to a different system unless things are fixed. For the price you pay for this system, things should work very well.

title: Nest Aware is NOT compatible with iOS!
text: Beware!! If you "upgrade" to Google's Nest Aware service, you will NOT be able to use Nest on your iPhone or iPad! The app works for about 30 seconds at a time before it crashes. This is due to Google streaming the video in a format not compatible with iOS devices. Your phone will become hot as it converts the feed "on the fly" which rapidly degrades battery and overloads the processor causing the app to crash. We had been using Nest for years and Google stepped in, bought the company, and is now ruining what was an awesome product. Used to use Nest as our crib cam, but now had to buy a video baby monitor because the Nest app became unusable. If you haven't upgraded to Nest Aware, the app works terrifically. It started crashing immediately after we upgraded the service. This is all over their forums and they have not addressed it for months--keeping in mind they have all the resources on the world, it is clear that addressing this is not a priority. Do not hold your breath for a fix

title: A very good purchase!
text: I think I’ve had my Nest thermostat for maybe three years, by now, or maybe longer. The control ability via the app is great and I use it often. I just turned the heat up 2 degrees because I was feeling a little chilly, and I never had to get up from my living room sofa. Also, the “learning” feature is awesome! The temperature is adjusted up during the heating season just before I get out of bed and it’s turned down to the night time setting about 45 minutes before I go to bed. I don’t have to do anything! When we go camping, I put it on “away” to conserve energy; and from my cell phone I set the Nest to “home” about an hour before I get home. We don’t come home to a hot or cold house! I really appreciate the technology in this gadget!

title: APP (not product) Review-App broken iOS 14
text:
This is a place to rate applications, not products. If you’re on here talking about anything unrelated to the actual app, you’re not helping, you’re making it more difficult for rational people to help them find and fix app issues. This isn’t Google or Yelp, ask a teenager for help if you don’t understand that simple reality. 

Since updating to iOS 14, I am unable to control my third gen. thermostat. The app “appears” to reflect my changes, but the thermostat does not. I now have to go to the thermostat every time I wish to change the setting. I look at the app on my phone, and it shows the change. There is clearly an issue in the app communication to the device all of a sudden. App often shows “offline”, even though the thermostat itself is most definitely online. I checked again after writing this review and it’s reporting “offline”, while I’m staring at the thermostat, online.

title: Plus security
text:
We have 2 homes approximately 100 miles apart. The more vulnerable house has the security system which is cameras (9) and the nests (5). 
1st incident: we noticed the humidity going up on the family room nest and at the same time we noticed a shadow enlarging away from the wall. After watching for a while as the humidity reading was increasing we decided to go to the house. And low and behold we found that a baseboard heater pipe has broken. 
2nd incident: The 5 nests were indicating the circulators were running but the temperature in the rooms was not warming up. We called our plumber and we all headed to the house and found there was no flame or ignition on the boiler.  
If not for the nests we probably would have had frozen water pipes in both scenarios.

title: Annoying
text: I have never paid so much attention to my thermostat or had to visit it so often to adjust the temperature, as I have since I got Nest!  Every time I adjust the thermostat to the temperature I want, within minutes (always less than 30 minutes, often less than 15), I notice that Nest has decided that IT knows what the temperature should be better than I know, & the temperature setting has been significantly altered - changed from the setting I had just set!  It is CONSTANTLY changing MY settings.  I am so over this thermostat - I regret replacing my old one - which I could program for 7 days, up to 4 settings  a day, and it was reliable.  I was always comfortable in my own house, now I am mostly too hot or, more often, too cold, and repeatedly having to Re-set the temperature that I just set a few minutes earlier!!  It’s ridiculous!  Best needs to make a better product that is, maybe a lot less “smart”!

title: Frequent logouts, Home/Away Assist unreliable
text:
I’ve had a Nest home cam for some time, and recently added a doorbell, an outdoor camera, and a thermostat.

The Home/Away Assist feature is frustratingly unreliable. There are two of us in the household, each of us using our own Google ID to log into Nest and set up Home/Away assist. Every few days, one of us gets randomly logged out of Nest, even though we keep the app always running. The Nest can’t figure out if anyone is home or not. I then have to go into the app to manually set the status or turn a camera on or off. Sometimes I have to drill down deep in the settings to determine if it’s logged in or not, even as the app cheerfully streams live video. I have to look for a little yellow exclamation mark and the message that “we haven’t heard from your phone in awhile.” (The phone has been literally running the app continuously!)

Then after logging in, Nest acts like we’ve never logged in before, asks everything about using the Google ID and setting up Home/Away for the same user that was previously logged in.

Finally, you can’t change the tone used for notifications from the iPhone default, which is ridiculous.

I’m willing to bet that the Nest app will eventually disappear into the Google Home app. I prefer the Nest home screen, so I’m sure they’ll take that away.

title: Needs an update
text:
I recently had Nest installed in my home and it is not working properly. I’ve entered my schedule (and that was a headache) and noticed heat was not turning on or off as scheduled. I looked at my schedule and it had dropped off or changed the temperature settings. This has happened repeatedly to me. Please update this! 
I have Home Away activated as well, but sometimes doesn’t know that I am not home (yes I have it set to track my iPhone). 
PLEASE WORK OUT THESE GLITCHES. 
Could animals trigger it (nest thinks someone home if animal movement)? But my animals are cats and not at height of nest thermostat so?

title: Safety for parents
text:
I’m using The nest cameras to make sure that my parents are safe. It has given me great peace of mind because I can check on them at any time of day or night.
My dad lives in a nice assisted living. He’s had many strokes and can not communicate with words, or in writing....so he cannot call me. I can look in on him and talk with him. By seeing how he’s moving around, I can tell how he’s doing. One night I saw his feet laid on the floor and knew he had fallen. I was then able to call for help right away.
My mom lives with me and has had several falls. If I go to the store, I can look in on mom to see how she’s doing. If I see she’s napping, I know I can get a few more errands run. It’s like another helper for me to better care for my parents.
My parents are 89!

title: Great for a snowbird
text: Bought my first one on recommend by my son who does a lot of traveling away from home for work. I’m a snow bird and I installed in my Florida home to help keep eye on the humidity and AC unit during summer months when I’m not there. I really recommend this product also I  like it changes the Ac or Heat settings when it see my phone has left the home and puts it back when I return this helps on energy usage. title: Cellular & wii-fi confusion at times
text: It’s a well laid out and thoughtfully designed app that is very aesthetically pleasing to the eye. The only reason I do not give it 5 stars is it gets confused when I’m in my driveway and unlock the door. During such instances the app seems to be prioritizing my weak (when outside) wi-fi signal over my cellular and because of this I get an error message that it “can’t connect” and to “Try again”. So it sometimes takes closing and reopening the app and needing to do it twice or more in order to work. A way around this is to of course open the app well prior to getting into the driveway and having my cell service used to connect as opposed to the app trying to connect to the Wifi. But I sometimes forget!

title: Nest thermostat
text: I really enjoy this thermostat. I’ve had it for a good solid year now and it literally does detect when you’re away from home if you have the app and have it set up that way. I love it because it syncs to our routines and lowers energy costs I also enjoy that it lights up as i walk by it to let me know like hey I’m still here this is what’s going on and I always rely on it to tell me temps not only inside the home but outside as well. I can always tell if it’s heating or cooling based on the orange and blue settings it shows and it’s very easy to use/ set up but at the same time very techy. title: Great but ……….

title: Mixed bag
text: This is my first time with a Nest thermostat. Previously had an Echo. It is fairly easy to navigate and setup. Does a fair job of learning your routine. title: Terrible! What Happened...
text:

title: Nest app very irritating

title: App lags too often
text: I love the prospect of this app but for $300 a year annually this app should work flawlessly. Every time I want to view my video history it take forever to load. title: Nest thermostats
text:
We have two in our home in Wisconsin, and one in our Florida cottage. They are great to control the settings from in bed on your mobile phone or across the country to check on the HVAC system.
One issue to be aware of now that Google is in the picture (as of May 2019) is that notifications may be sent changing your schedule due to what Big Brother thinks it’s learned about your activity or needed energy savings. I can’t locate the copy of the message as I write this review, but our schedule and temperature settings were changed w/o our permission or acknowledgment causing guests to not feel comfortable. The notice didn’t require much awareness to try increasing efficiency and caused a problem with comfort.

title: Status light and false notifications.
text: My dog is consistently recognized as a human and sets off the notification that a person is in my home whenever he stretches out, which is several times a day, creating a chicken little effect.  Additionally, the ability to turn off the status light indicator was removed several months ago.  Now the cameras I have setup in windows reflect a bright blue light in the video that I record on outward facing cameras.  Additionally, it draws attention to the cameras which makes them easily spotted and allows for blind spots in the setup to be identified and alerts any would be thieves that they should take care to cover their faces when entering their field of view.  For my purposes the status light indicators not being able to be turned off, except in connection or troubleshooting issues, is counter productive.  Being able to override these settings manually is a choice that I as an end user would like to maintain.

title: Slow, useless, clumsy
text: Prepare to want to throw your phone. The features are somewhat straight forward, but not really. The biggest problems are constant resyncing of your phone to the Nest, the in-app speed is painfully slow at updating, to the point where you’ll think the app has frozen. Notifications are useless and CONSTANT, until you turn them off. Be prepared for “quirks”...yes, I promise you it will change your set points, not per the “learning” feature, it will set your set points to more “green” settings, 100% regardless of how many times you turn off the green feature, or reprogram your schedule. The nest was absolutely not worth the money, the painful app, and everything else. Buy a Honeywell.

title: Please fix app is buggy and broken after iOS 14 launch
text: App needs updated to work with the new Apple software update iOS 14 on the iPhone 11 Pro Max when using the app the security cameras barely work with the app now and have to load every couple seconds instead of being able to stream them live it loads after a few seconds every time and takes at least 20 seconds to load making the live indoor and outdoor nest cameras useless and when you open the app the security camera feed hardly ever shows up you have to keep opening and closing the app until your security cameras finally work. title: Hard to control

title: Won’t stay Connected to App since the 5.6.7.0 update

title: Technology is great!
text:
I have now had my Nesr thermostat for several years. I don’t use the schedule feature much but what I love about it is that, summer or winter, I can set the temperature using my iPhone. In the summer when we have warm nights, I will turn the air-conditioning on mine when I get in bed. I I turn off the air when I first wake up and open the house to let the cool area.

title: Nest Thermostats
text:
Works pretty good for the most part, usually responsive with little lag time. New devices are easily set up. Being able to control when away from home is a huge perk. 

The home/away feature is great but every persons phone has to be connected for it to operate correctly (my wife’s wasn’t for a while, so nest would go into eco mode while she slept if i left for work). 

The scheduling however is pretty poor and the reason it loses a star. Autoscheculing seems to take a while to learn and adjusts to pretty much every time you touch the thermostat (say if you have guests over and want some cool air). I gave up on it. Manual schedules work well but are tedious to set up on the app (maybe a web based scheduling feature could help) but work well once in place.

title: Pathetic for interacting with your Nest ecosystem
text:
The app mangers clearly give zero craps about how a polished iOS app works. There are no widgets for this app, no "quick actions", nothing was done to make using this app easy.

Every launch of the app takes you back to the home screen, even when you just switched away for a moment. There are no quick links that can take you directly to a device (e.g. to unlock my Yale/Nest lock). Often launching the app takes me to a "Sign up for feature X" screen that I have to dismiss before actually using the app! What the??!? Shockingly bad user experience.

Recent updates to the app have broken the Nest doorbell camera viewing completely. Trying to scrub through video causes the app to freeze while my phone becomes lava hot.

title: Much better option out there
text:
Update*** so the option to scroll through video was not removed the app was just not working properly which still proves my point. 

Long time nest user that just updated to ios14. Nest continues to go downhill and has just taken away the ability to scroll through your video. Adding fuel to the file these cameras continue to live connectivity each day. I guess I’ll have a ton of paper weights when I invest in a new system that actually keep the use in mind.

title: Loved but hard to trust
text:
I have been a huge supporter of the Nest brand for a long time. I have many products from cameras to the thermostats, temp sensors, and protects. But the app continues to be left behind with constant stability issues. I rely on this app and it’s products to help protect my home and offer convenience and peace of mind but as of late that peace of mind has been slowly dwindling. 

The new Google Home App is just not anywhere close to the Nest app. It requires more taps or pages to do one thing it seems and doesn’t even support the temp sensors that are tied to my  ear thermostats :(

I’m still loving the ecosystem I bought into but fear my love will bite me soon. Considering the newest Nest cams only work in the Google Home App worries me greatly and is keeping me from buying them. But at the same time, my Nest apps continues to crash and be unstable.

title: Nest 2nd generation soundcheck
text:
Gave full access to my wife, she gained access, I was not receiving  pre sound check notification, and sometimes not getting when it was completed. After few weeks of troubleshooting with Nest support, as nothing was corrected, I gave up. Today we both got pre sound check notification, sound check was completed and only I got the completion notification. When looked into her phone app, I noticed it says: “As of last month you no longer have access to Nest”!
I totally gave up! Done!  I guess it is what it is! The concept is excellent, but it’s good when it’s functional. Who knows in case of a real fire will I get notified when I’m away? Not thrust worthy!

title: UnReadable Temperatures
text:
This app function perfectly… For Google.  Unfortunately for human beings with normal eyesight it is almost unusable. 
Nest (and Google) have taken the position that this is a controller device and Not a thermostat. 
That would be OK if they would accept the fact that people are the primary users, not computers. 
On the device, you can have a giant number showing what temperature the house should be at, and a tiny little number that tells you that, yes, you are cold, or hot. 
This app is designed by the same non-human. The display will show you what you want but not what you have.   It is not a matter of available space most of the apps screen is completely empty. The least they could do is make the two settings the same size, and let me use the giant screen I paid for on my Apple device.

title: Wish I had bought earlier
text: My goodness, I absolutely....without a doubt absolutely love this Nest thermostat. I have the latest generation, third or fourth; but it’s the latest. I absolutely love this thing. It will remove the humidity, tell me when I’m saving energy remembers how I like it in my home and when I’m due to be back it makes sure it’s the temp I like when I’m home. But when I’m away it knows it and saves me energy by not keeping it so cool. It will also when it sees it’s possible to do so turn off the A/C compressor and just use the fan to keep my home circulated with heat or cool air. If your looking to put one of these in your home stop procrastinating and do it now!!  I promise you will be as delighted as I am.

title: Good system until there is a power failure
text: I like using Nest to control my home thermostat remotely but I think the system has a major design flaw. When there is a power outage and the internet connection is lost, Nest goes off line ( which is understandable); but that means heat/AC stops functioning. The problem is that once power is restored and internet is back Nest requires that the router be rebooted before thermostat starts functioning again.  If you are not physically on premises the system stays off line which makes controlling home temperature impossible and potentially dangerous in winter where cold temps cause pipes to freeze.  I’ve had to ask neighbors to go inside my house and reboot my system as I am away on business a lot— poor design and VERY inconvenient !

title: You done messed up G-Google

But to my surprise, the lovely developers decided even though you pay for a service, they will take away your ability to scrub through your 24/7 footage as you’ve done for years. title: Feels Like Luxury
text:
First, let me state that I’ve zero problems with my Nest set-up or functioning. Nest's online/shared wifi troubleshooting has got me through every not-fully-understanding moment. I highly recommend Nest home thermostat. 

I’m ever conscious of power costs AND also need my bedroom very, very cool (summer and winter) to be able to sleep. Setting TEMP SCHEDULES with Nest is one little life luxury. I come home from work very late at night, to my pre-cooled home. I’m in the desert and refuse to leave a thermostat anywhere close to sleep-comfort temps, winter or summer, while I’m at work, and especially when we’re in nonstop high-90s/triple-digit summer days.
 
REMOTE ACCESS is my Favorite Toy, for two reasons. 
1. I have house guests and I’ve forgot to either change the schedules or WARN 🥴the guest(s) they may start to roast 🥵 mid-afternoon, and wall thermostat will need adjustment. 
2. I fall in the category of 'elderly' 💁🏼‍♀️! I have old bones that hurt, big time, most of the time. Hauling myself out of bed to adjust temps is never pain free, it’s a project. Changing the thermostat from bed is an absolute, I’m-in-big-time-luxury, for me!

title: Useless without subscription
text: It is more expensive than others. On top of that, you need to pay 60 dollars each year forever… it is absurdly overpriced. The responsiveness is slow compared to my other doorbell from eufy; and I have a very fast network. The product review only reviews the doorbell under subscription (since it is free for some time after activation). But without subscription, it is useless. The motion alerts are always late; they show no video but just a picture that is 9 out of 10 captured with delay and thus it shows no person or very far. There is NO reason for paying forever for a SUBSCRIPTION. Absurd! Buy something else and stop paying monthly “small” subscription fees for stuff shouldn’t have one. Then you get rid off the doorbell and forget the subscription and will be paying for a long time. Plus, with so many ‘cheat’ subscriptions, have you calculated how much is per year? For what?

title: Great when it works
text: Constantly dropping the WiFi connection makes for frustrating monitoring. When it does connect the resolution is excellent and the night vision better than I had expected - somewhat like a poor resolution b&w video but clear. The audio is a nice feature and the bi-directional functionality makes it my version of “ring”. The transmission lag is minimal compared to other less expensive cameras I have tried and removed. Overall an excellent product, I just wish the WiFi connection was better. In fairness, I don’t have the best WiFi network but I do not have the frequent drops with any other products (computers, Roku, smart TVs, etc). I give it a 4 for the connection issues but a 5 as a camera, app, and ease of installation.

title: I expected better from Google
text:
The app is confusing at times. I’m looking at a screen showing the current view of the camera. It says “Today” and there is an old clip of a delivery as well. The clip has a time next to it, but doesn’t say which day it was recorded. Also, while you are watching a clip there is no progress indicator.
 
As for the cloud part, frequently it is unable to load clips and just shows the circle spinning indicator. And there is no evidence of smart machine learning here. I get frequent motion clips of insects and dripping water. Wind noises and airplanes are reported as talking. 

Finally I don’t think I get notifications for all the events I should. The cameras are very expensive and app performed even more poorly without the monthly subscription.  I feel like any recorded clips were stored on a very overloaded server.  Also there have been no notable improvements in over a year. I am very disappointed.

title: Nest on heat pump
text:
The nest thermostat is great. Took a while to get it set up for the heat pump so it would automatically switch from cool to heat a d to auxiliary heat without calling in there professional, but with a lot of research on the internet I got everything working hot it should.

I can adjust the temperature from anywhere with my iPhone (anywhere in the house and while I am away from home) without having to get up or have someone go to my house while I am away. It’s great.

This is easily the dumbest thermostat I’ve ever used.

title: Like having a roommate that messes with the thermostat
text:
If you are happy with any temperature setting, this device is cool. But if you are particular about the temperature in your house, this isn't for you. You don't get to decide the temperature you live with, nest does! It's truly like a ghost lives in your house who likes it super warm.

title: Manual schedule adjustment is terrible
text:
Manually adjusting the schedule in the Nest app has probably the worst user experience I've ever encountered in a Google app. It's virtually impossible to add anything at exactly 12am between Sunday and Monday. The closest I could get was 11:45 or 12:15, by tapping very carefully. Then, if I tried to drag the circle closer, it would only snap to 10:30 or 1:30 — further away! Speaking of dragging the circles, something is wrong with the sensitivity, because if I tried to drag left or right, it frequently got locked to up and down instead (or vice versa). Then, I'd need to adjust it back AND try again to do what I wanted originally. Eventually, I would get it, but thinking about people with limited mobility, that's an accessibility nightmare.

The thermostat itself is great. It's just the scheduling part of the Nest app that could really use improvement.

title: Used to work great
text:
Prior to google taking over, the app and devices used to work great. Now I am subject to multiple resets and forced to login several times, sometimes in the middle of using the app to review something the camera captured (reason for a camera) I will be force logged out and have to login. Doesn’t make any sense. The nest app still works better for me than the app google is trying to force users to, and even flows better. Also, I have lost count of the number of times I want the app to use my phone to trigger away status. Feels like at least once a week. (Which May make sense of it was due to an update)

I do appreciate they were proactive in refunds when the service went down awhile back. 

The hardware is great, haven’t had any issues with it so far.

title: New ‘Sign in with Google’ makes sharing not caring
text:
Best recently changed Nest to a sign in with Google app. I nanny for my niece and used to use Nest to monitor the kids when they were on their rooms; but, my niece doesn’t want me to have access to her Google account; and, I don’t want to have access to her google account. That’s just stupid. My sister, her mother used to have access to Nest, too. There’s also a baby sitter who comes in a couple times a week who used to use it. 

 Nest is great to monitor what the kids are doing in their rooms upstairs: are they still asleep, did they get out of bed, are they getting dressed, are they at their desk doing homework or dancing around, are they stuck between the bed and the wall, did they get into the ointments on the changing table instead of taking a nap. 

As nanny, I watch the 3 kids 40 hours a week. Before Covid, it was more like 55-60 but now my niece and her husband are home more. I can’t use the Nest cameras. I could respond to the kids waking up from a nap quickly; I could see when something like getting stuck between the bed and the wall happened; I could run up and stop a kid from pulling on the curtains. Now I have to rely on the sounds from the room and wait for a kid to yell before I know they’re up. 

Nest has gone down to less than 50% of its usefulness in the house.

title: Would Not Recommend!
text:
Google continues to smear the great company that Nest created by ruining the functionality of its app. The lag time from when a person is viewed by my cameras to the time of the notification is horrendous! They aren’t timely enough in any way for someone to actually act upon them. There really is no point to the notification features, except as a brief on the activity from the night or day.
